The capital of France is Paris.

It is the country's most populous city and its center for politics, finance, commerce, and culture.

Key Facts about Paris

Location: Situated in the north-central part of the country along the Seine River, within the Île-de-France region.

Population: The city proper has a population of approximately 2.1 million, while the broader metropolitan area is home to over 13 million people.

Significance: Paris is one of the world's major centers for art, fashion, gastronomy, and culture. It is famously nicknamed "The City of Light" (La Ville Lumière).

Quantum entanglement is a phenomenon where two tiny particles (like electrons or photons) become linked in a way that they share a single existence. Even if you separate them by billions of miles, they remain connected.

When you measure the state of one particle, the other particle instantly changes its state to match or oppose it, faster than the speed of light.

Here is a simple breakdown of how it works.

1. The Core Concept: "The Magic Coins"

To understand entanglement, we have to forget how normal objects work.

Imagine you have two coins. You keep one and give the other to a friend who travels to the other side of the galaxy.

In the normal world: If you look at your coin and it is "Heads," that doesn't change anything about your friend's coin. They are independent.

In the Quantum world (Entanglement): Imagine these are "Magic Entangled Coins." While they are flying through space, they are not Heads or Tails yet. They are both spinning (a state called Superposition).

The moment you catch your spinning coin and see that it is Heads:

Your friend's coin instantly stops spinning.

It becomes Tails.

It doesn't matter that your friend is light-years away. The moment you "forced" your coin to decide a state, the other coin "knew" and instantly assumed the opposite state.

2. Why is this so weird?

This phenomenon upset many famous physicists, including Albert Einstein.

Common Sense says: Objects should have a set state (like a pair of shoes in boxes—if you have the left one, the right one is definitely in the other box).

Quantum Mechanics says: The "shoes" don't decide if they are left or right until you open the box.

Einstein famously called this "Spooky action at a distance" because it seemed to break the rule that nothing can travel faster than light.

3. The Catch: No "Faster-Than-Light" Texting

You might think, "Great! I can use this to send instant messages to Mars!"

Unfortunately, you can't.

You cannot control which side your coin lands on. It is random.

You might get Heads, Heads, Tails, Heads.

Your friend sees Tails, Tails, Heads, Tails.

Your friend sees a random pattern just like you do. They only know it’s a message if you call them (using regular, slower-than-light radio) and compare your notes. Therefore, no actual information travels faster than light.

4. What is it used for?

Even though we can't use it for instant texting, entanglement is the power source behind two major technologies:

Quantum Computers: They use entangled particles to perform calculations that are impossible for supercomputers.

Quantum Cryptography: It allows us to create "unhackable" codes. If a hacker tries to "peek" at the entangled particles while they are being sent, the entanglement breaks (the coins stop spinning), and the receiver knows instantly that the line is tapped.

Summary Table

Feature	Classical World (Normal)	Quantum World (Entangled)
State	Definite (It is Heads or Tails)	Undefined (Spinning/Superposition)
Connection	None (Independent)	Linked (One system)
Distance	Distance delays connection	Distance doesn't matter
Analogy	Two different emails	Two magic dice
Export to Sheets

The history of the internet is a complex evolution from a government defense project to a global utility that connects billions of people. It is generally divided into several distinct eras, moving from infrastructure building to the creation of the user-friendly World Wide Web.

Here is a summary of the key milestones in the history of the internet.

1. The Cold War & Conceptualization (1950s–1969)

The internet was born out of the Cold War. After the Soviet Union launched Sputnik in 1957, the US Department of Defense formed ARPA (Advanced Research Projects Agency) to ensure US military technology remained superior.

Packet Switching: Researchers Paul Baran (USA) and Donald Davies (UK) independently developed the concept of breaking data into small "packets" to be sent across a network. This ensured that if one line was destroyed, data could find another route—a crucial requirement for nuclear survivability.

ARPANET (1969): The first precursor to the internet. On October 29, 1969, the first message ("LO") was sent from a computer at UCLA to one at Stanford. It was supposed to be "LOGIN," but the system crashed after two letters.

2. Developing the Language (1970s)

In the 1970s, different networks began to spring up, but they could not talk to one another. They needed a common language.

TCP/IP (1974): Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn developed the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP). This architecture allowed distinct networks to interconnect.

Email (1971): Ray Tomlinson sent the first network email and chose the @ symbol to separate the user from the machine.

3. Expansion and Unification (1980s)

The 1980s marked the transition from a purely military experimental network to an academic and scientific tool.

Flag Day (1983): ARPANET officially switched to TCP/IP on January 1, 1983. Many consider this the official "birthday of the Internet" because it created a unified network of networks.

DNS (1983): The Domain Name System was invented. Instead of remembering IP addresses (like 192.0.2.1), users could now type memorable names like .com, .edu, and .gov.

NSFNET (1986): The National Science Foundation funded a high-speed backbone to connect supercomputer centers, effectively replacing ARPANET and opening the network to more universities.

4. The World Wide Web & The Public (1990s)

Before the 90s, the internet was text-based and difficult to use. This decade changed everything by introducing a graphical interface.

The World Wide Web (1990): Sir Tim Berners-Lee, a scientist at CERN, invented HTML, HTTP, and the first web browser. Note: The "Web" is the pages/content; the "Internet" is the pipes/infrastructure.

Mosaic (1993): The first user-friendly web browser that displayed images inline with text. This popularized surfing the web.

Commercialization (1995): Restrictions on commercial traffic were lifted. Companies like Amazon, Google (1998), and eBay were founded, leading to the "Dot-com boom."

5. The Modern Era: Web 2.0 & Mobile (2000s–Present)

The internet shifted from static pages (read-only) to dynamic platforms (read-write) and eventually became ubiquitous.

Broadband: Dial-up was replaced by high-speed always-on connections.

Web 2.0 (Mid-2000s): The rise of user-generated content and social media. Facebook (2004) and YouTube (2005) changed the internet from a library into a community.

The Mobile Internet (2007): The release of the iPhone brought the full desktop-class internet to pockets, fundamentally changing how humans interact with digital information.

IoT (Internet of Things): Today, the internet connects not just people, but appliances, cars, and industrial machinery.

Key Distinction: Internet vs. World Wide Web

People often use these terms interchangeably, but they are different.

Feature	The Internet	The World Wide Web
Definition	A massive network of networks (hardware/infrastructure).	A way of accessing information over the medium of the Internet.
Analogy	The railroad tracks.	The trains and cargo.
Key Protocols	TCP/IP	HTTP / HTTPS
Age	Origins in the late 1960s.	Origins in 1989/1990.
Export to Sheets

Interesting Fact: The internet is held together physically by hundreds of thousands of miles of submarine cables on the ocean floor, not satellites. Satellites account for a very small percentage of global traffic.

Here is a recipe for Classic Lasagna.

This recipe uses the traditional Béchamel sauce (a creamy white sauce) rather than ricotta cheese. This method, typical of Northern Italy (Lasagne alla Bolognese), creates a richer, silkier texture that melts in your mouth.

Prep & Cook Time

Prep: 45 mins

Cook: 45 mins

Total: 1 hr 30 mins

Servings: 8–10

Ingredients

1. The Meat Sauce (Ragù)

2 tbsp Olive oil

1 Yellow onion, finely chopped

1 Carrot, finely chopped

1 Celery stalk, finely chopped

1 lb (450g) Ground beef (lean)

1/2 lb (225g) Italian sausage (mild or spicy, casings removed) or ground pork

2 cloves Garlic, minced

1/2 cup Red wine (dry, like Cabernet or Merlot) - optional, can sub with beef broth

1 can (28 oz) Crushed tomatoes

2 tbsp Tomato paste

1 tsp Dried oregano (or Italian seasoning)

Salt & Pepper to taste

2. The Béchamel (White Sauce)

4 tbsp Unsalted butter

1/4 cup All-purpose flour

3 1/2 cups Whole milk (warmed slightly)

1/4 tsp Nutmeg (freshly grated is best)

1/2 cup Parmesan cheese, grated

Salt & White Pepper to taste

3. The Assembly

1 lb (450g) Lasagna noodles (no-boil or boiled according to package)

2 cups Mozzarella cheese, shredded

1 cup Parmesan cheese, grated (for topping)

Instructions

Step 1: Make the Meat Sauce

Sauté Veggies: Heat olive oil in a large pot/Dutch oven over medium heat. Add onion, carrot, and celery. Cook for 5–7 minutes until soft. Add garlic and cook for 1 minute.

Brown Meat: Increase heat to medium-high. Add the beef and sausage. Break up the meat with a spoon and cook until browned. Drain excess fat if needed.

Simmer: Stir in the tomato paste and cook for 1 minute to deepen the flavor. Pour in the red wine and scrape the bottom of the pot (deglaze) to release browned bits. Let it bubble for 2 minutes.

Finish Sauce: Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and pepper. Bring to a simmer, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 20–30 minutes while you make the white sauce.

Step 2: Make the Béchamel (Creamy White Sauce)

Make Roux: In a medium saucepan, melt butter over medium heat. Whisk in the flour and cook for 1–2 minutes until it smells slightly nutty (do not let it brown).

Add Milk: Gradually pour in the warm milk slowly while whisking constantly to prevent lumps.

Thicken: Simmer gently for 5–8 minutes, stirring frequently, until the sauce thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon.

Season: Remove from heat. Stir in the nutmeg, 1/2 cup Parmesan, salt, and pepper.

Step 3: Assemble

Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).

Base: Spread a thin layer of meat sauce on the bottom of a 9x13 inch baking dish.

Layer 1: Place a layer of lasagna noodles (overlap slightly if needed). Spread 1/3 of the remaining meat sauce over noodles. Drizzle 1/3 of the béchamel sauce on top. Sprinkle with a little mozzarella.

Layer 2 & 3: Repeat the pattern: Noodles -> Meat Sauce -> Béchamel -> Mozzarella.

Top Layer: Finish with a final layer of noodles. Top with the remaining béchamel (spread to the edges to keep noodles moist) and the remaining mozzarella and Parmesan cheese.

Step 4: Bake

Cover: Cover the dish with aluminum foil (spray foil with oil so cheese doesn't stick). Bake for 25 minutes.

Uncover: Remove foil and bake for another 15–20 minutes until the cheese is bubbly and golden brown.

Rest: Let the lasagna rest for at least 15 minutes before slicing. This is crucial—if you cut it too soon, the layers will slide apart.

Quick Variation (American Style with Ricotta)

If you prefer the American style or want to save time by skipping the Béchamel:

Swap: Replace the Béchamel ingredients with 15 oz Ricotta cheese mixed with 1 egg, 1/2 cup Parmesan, and chopped parsley.

Layering: Spread the Ricotta mixture on the noodles instead of the white sauce.
